timeline.bodyText: This method was not really related to EdgeAccess.
timeline.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: This -1 appeared frequently, and was the only value used for this parameter
timeline.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: I renamed this for consistency with the other iterator class names.
timeline.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: Moved this one level up, its hardly related to the iterator but its more like the initialization code of an edge state
timeline.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: Renamed this because its more like an 'edge' than an iterator. Its used as base class for the iterators yes, but there wasn't much that was 'iterator-like' about this class.
timeline.author: easbar

replies.bodyText: Thanks! I think it is probably time to try again if we can separate the EdgeIterator interface from EdgeIteratorState (the last time I tried this it was still to heavily coupled in CH but maybe now this is possible?)
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Ok, but why would this be better? An EdgeIterator is just an EdgeIteratorState with a next() method. I don't think this ever bothered me.
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText: Hmmh, my argument would be that they should be separated like Object is separate from Iterator, but yes, here we change the properties of "Object" with every iterator.next() call and so EdgeIterator is not really an Iterator it is more an EdgeIteratorState with a setPointer/setCursor method (very similar to the ResultSet from jdbc API)
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText:
Ok for me an EdgeIteratorState is a proxy to a row of data, or in some cases its an actual row of data (after calling detach()). An EdgeIterator is the same thing except that it can be moved to another edge. I think @michaz suggested calling it a 'cursor' because it changes state after calling next(), compared to the java.util.Iterator which returns the next element when calling next(). But honestly, I am so used to it I do not really care whether its called iterator or cursor. But I do not see real value in separating EdgeIteratorState from EdgeIterator, because like I said in this case the latter is really the same thing as the first except that it allows to be shifted (using the next() method).
Now we are at it how would we call an EdgeIteratorState that can be set to an arbitrary edge (not just move to the next edge at the same base node). Would it be a SingleEdgeExplorer or a SingleEdgeIterator or a SingleEdgeCursor? 😃
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
Probably the EdgeIterator is not a "cursor" because it has no direct setEdgeId method, only an implicit "next()" and so "iterator" is more appropriate (?)

Now we are at it how would we call an EdgeIteratorState that can be set to an arbitrary edge (not just move to the next edge at the same base node).

I like SingleEdgeCursor (also it would have an explicit setEdgeId :) ? )
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Ok yes SingleEdgeCursor is good and avoids the confusion of calling it "iterator" or "explorer" :) Yes its main method would be setEdgeId (or setEdge or moveToEdge(Id) or `setToEdge(Id)?).
replies.author: easbar
easbar

replies.bodyText: Ohhhh, yes yes yes yes yes, standard iteration syntax, please. :-)
replies.author: michaz

timeline.bodyText: The chFlags shouldn't belong to this (basegraph) iterator, I guess this was forgotten in some previous refactoring
timeline.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: BTW: I'm not sure if it is a good thing to do these logic checks via if instead of `assert' as they could have a potential slow down, but I wasn't able to measure this difference and so I preferred long term safety (i.e. show these problems even in production)
timeline.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Hm yes good question. An integer comparison == should hardly ever matter? Except the method gets too long and is no longer inlined or something? Very hard or impossible to say without measuring.
replies.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: I think we should always update the edgePointer to the new value before returning.
timeline.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Hm, if false is returned we are not using the iterator anymore? But maybe you are right and its more consistent the way you proposed. Should not matter performance-wise, because usually it has to be updated anyway (unless we are at the end of the iteration)
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText: But then we need to update adjNode and baseNode etc. as well? I think using the iterator after iter.next() == false is not well defined anyway? I always used it like this so far while (iter.next()) { // do sth }
replies.author: easbar
